challengeName: Service Order Entry - Build out a POS Console on Salesforce.com
detailedRequirements:
Overview

Welcome to the Service Order Entry for Service Cloud Console challenge, brought to you by Salesforce.com!

We are looking to develop an order entry UI for the Service Cloud Console that is as easy to use as Amazon.com or REI.com. We are looking to create a simple, efficient and intuitive UI that will appeal to large B2C retail organizations that need the ability to sell and serve from the same application and takes advantage of Salesforce.com’s Omni-channel capability to provide an effortless experience for agent and customer alike.

High Level Requirements

The key focus of this challenge is to build a package that:

  1. Allows an agent to quickly search for products by product number or description

  2. Add product a cart or order

  3. Quickly return to browsing other product and add additional products

  4. Allow for upsell/cross-sell or similar or related products

  5. Quickly access detailed product information

  6. Complete the sales order and collect payment

  7. Quickly access existing or past orders to edit or change

Detailed Requirements

1 - Console

  1. Build out a Custom Service Cloud Console that includes Accounts, Orders and Products

2 - Accounts

  1. Simulate an incoming call and open Account Detail Page (New Account or Existing Account) based on the caller

    1. This is achieved by the Softphone Layouts.

3 - Orders

  1. Add Orders related list to Account Details Page

    1. Add “New Order” button to Account Detail page as well as on the Orders Related list.

  2. Clicking on New order button should open a new tab with New Order Standard UI

    1. New Order should not have Contracts fields (Please remove any references to the Contracts field)

    2. Add additional Statuses to the Order Object-  Shipped, Returned, Cancelled, Completed, In Progress (or we can use Activated), Draft

  3. Use the Standard Order Product Related List to add the products to the Order

  4. Add a new Custom Console Component, which will show the Order Summary with selected products (see Screenshot). The Component should have a button for Checkout, and also remove option next to each product in Order summary. (if the cart is empty, display “ your cart is empty ”

4 - Products

  1. Add custom fields, Picture (URL or RTA), Availability (flag?), Product Specification (RTA)

    1. Add two custom objects linked to Product as parent

      1. Product Review

        1. Review By (Account Lookup)

        2. Review (RTA or TA)

        3. Review Date

        4. Rating (1 to 5)

      2. Product Q&A

        1. Question

        2. Answer

        3. Answered by (User Lookup)

  2. Add a Custom Console Component (Visualforce page) specific to Product Object (add it to Product page layout) that shows the Product’s details, price, Quantity and also has a button “Add to Cart” (see sample screenshot).

  3. Add a Custom Console Component (Visualforce page) specific to Product Object (at the bottom of Product Detail page), that shows product details(Product Description), Specs (Product Specification), Reviews and Q&A.

  4. Build a new Visualforce page for Order Checkout, which opens as a new tab in the Console, pull the information from Account about the User and add a Button “Submit Order” that will mark the order as Completed/Activated. (Note this is not yet linked to any POS system, maybe a future challenge).

  5. Add a Custom Console Component (Visualforce) that will show the list of similar products on the right sidebar (see Screenshot).  Use the Product Family field to pull the similar products.

Data Model

The Data Model for this challenge is based mostly on standard Salesforce objects. Feel free to add any additional objects/custom fields if needed.

  • Account

  • Order

    • Custom Fields might be required

  • Product

    • Custom Fields might be required

  • Product Review (Custom Object)

  • Product Q&A (Custom Object)

Storyboards

Included in the forums is a storyboard of screens to help illustrate how a user might interact with the Service Console, and where all the pieces might go.   These are just samples; you can improvise on these and build a better Console using your creativity. Use of Bootstrap / JS/ jQuery is recommended as they render real nice in the console.  See attached files in forums for more screenshots.

Design

We previously ran a design challenge using the included storyboards to get a suggestion for the look-and-feel of the app.  While it did not include standard Service Cloud components, you can see how we may be able to borrow from parts of the design for our components and inline VF pages. (We would not use the custom header, for example.  We would stick with the standard Salesforce UI for the the header/Console, but then use components of the design, such as the Order Summary section.)

We’ve included the winning design in the forums.  Use these files as guidelines to accompany the storyboards.  If you are able to reproduce the style of the designs within your components and VF pages, all the better.  But the main focus of this challenge is functionality over design.  If we need to, we will run a follow up challenge to update the CSS to match the design.

 

Resources

  1. Service Console Storyboards - Storyboards for UX flow.  Highlights where/how components might be included within the context of the Service Console

  2. Service Order Entry Platform Design - Designs for an eCommerce platform.  We can borrow from different sections as guidelines for look-and-feel.

  3. Salesforce Console Integration Toolkit Developer’s Guide - Guide for advanced customizations of the Service Console.

  4. Salesforce Developer Website - Getting started with Salesforce development.

  5. Console Overview - Introduction to Salesforce’s Console.
finalSubmissionGuidelines:
Code Guidelines

  • Aesthetics - Code must be clean (no commented code fragments, unused variables, etc.), tidy (4-space indents, ideally 80-char margins), and well-commented. Use clear and purposeful names for variables, classes, etc.

  • Unit Tests - You should target 90% code coverage for classes you develop, and all tests should pass.  Please include meaningful assertions, too.

    • Please also include one or more Systems tests. These should cover end-to-end usage, mimicking an end user’s steps.  Include comments

  • Scalability - Your app should support working with multiple records.

  • Production-Ready - Your app should be ready for production install.

    • Remove any unnecessary System.debug statements.

    • Remove any unused code.

    • Double-check spelling, especially for UIs.

Submission Deliverables

  • Source Code - Zip of source files (including all metadata files).

  • Unmanaged Package - Link to unmanaged package of same files.

  • Video - Video demonstrating setup of app (install + config), demo of app functionality, and overview of code.

  • Documentation - Provide documentation of setup (install/config) and steps for using the app.
